text: Anyone else having issues when trying to edit e-mails? I have this issue with 2 different HubSpot accounts and two different portals.
Yep. Website pages too.
<@UGDF9EBPW> and <@UB690RZA7> are you still seeing this issue? (may need to hard refresh the editor if you’re currently viewing)
<@U7SL518D6> seems to be working again. ty
<@U7SL518D6> Up and running again. Thanks!
I may have spoke too soon. It was working, now the loader icon is just spinning.
finally loaded with a 500 error

We’re monitoring the issue. Thanks for confirming it’s come back for you.

We have engineers looking into it, the issue appears to be intermittent.
Is there a way to stop clients uploading stupidly large images to HubSpot?
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/functions>
Are they wider than 4096? "Images that are larger than 4096 pixels in height or width will not be automatically resized."
Yep larger than 4096. Clients just go mental uploading images at like 7000px
One idea would be to create a small script to daily check new files added to the file manager. If an image is wider than 4096 it could email you and you can be the Image too big police!
raw images from a photoshoot or graphics from a brochure folder... I have seen this before and painful.
they are just images and they don't think how a mobile device will scream in pain.
<https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/files/get_files>
you could also go to file manager and sort by size once a month or something and look for any huge files.
maybe you should create an Idea if not one already to add an alert if an image if larger than 4096 so people can vote on it
The best thing you can do is educate, second - use tools like the HubSpot CDN to resize the images using the HubL function. Provide `width` `height` attributes and create custom srcsets if desired.
A common solution is to provide helptext in module image fields that suggest image dimensions.
Here’s a guide you can send to non-developers about resizing images <https://blog.HubSpot.com/marketing/compress-image>
This image format guide may also be useful to them <https://blog.HubSpot.com/insiders/different-types-of-image-files>
It doesn’t go into WebP - but that’s fine because HubSpot automatically progressively enhances jpg and png to webp

Hey all, do you know if the reverse proxy instructions <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/developer-reference/reverse-proxy-support#configure-your-proxy-to-forward-requests> are for the headers in HubSpot or in the place where the proxy is managed?

The headers in that section are headers you want to pass from your host where your proxy is managed. (not HubSpot)

They are headers required to make the reverse proxy function.
Thanks. The client wasn't sure if they they ALSO needed to match in HubSpot.
I'm assuming HubSpot needs to be left clear of any domain security settings?

Most of those headers you can’t control from HubSpot. Also wanted to share this Community post I wrote with some tips and a sample nginx config. <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/CMS-Development/Lessons-Learned-from-Setting-up-a-Reverse-Proxy-With-HubSpot-CMS/td-p/435961|https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/CMS-Development/Lessons-Learned-from-Setting-up-a-Reverse-Proxy-With-HubSpot-CMS/td-p/435961>

To your question about domain security- part of the setup process will pre-provision an SSL cert, and then if there are other security headers, if you require them, the proxy would need to work with them (depending which specifically you’re referencing)
that link is excellent ty!
Thanks! Glad you found it helpful!

Hello all,
I have some questions regarding iOS universal deeplinking. So is there anyone who can help me?
Is this the right group?
